body:
He,

thanks for the bug report and for tracking this down.

This is definitely strange and not expected or desired so I'd consider it a bug.

If you can come up with a nicer solution to this I'd be happy about a PR :)

cool.  the problem as i can see it is that at that stage the constraint just has an error message that was generated somewhere earlier in the chain and so it doesn't know within that scope what part of the message is phpunit text, and what part is the output from the expression that was being tested.

so one approach could be a more specific pattern matching, but i'm thinking that might not be able to catch everything.

a slightly more disruptive change would be for phpunit to generate it's text as a kind of simplistic template language and then right before it gets sent back, the search/replace happens.

for example the first constrain could generate a message like this:

```
Failed asserting that 'username not required' {{contains}} "required"
```

Then the Not constraint would be able to locate text generated by phpunit because it is surrounded by brackets and could safely replace {{contains}} with {{does not contain}}.

Lastly at the very end just before the result message is sent back, a global function could look for any template vars and replace them.

It seems kinda overkill for such a minor thing but I'm not sure there is a better way without doing some major plumbing changes.

Thanks for looking into that!

Not really sure what to do about it ether. Maybe the simplest case that might catch most of the issues is only doing the replace for stuff outside of single and double quotes.

Not sure. Leaving this open for anyone to pick up :)

issue.title: [BugFix] #764 "Not" constraints error message
issue.body: Issue #764 "Not" constraints generate a confusing error message

body:
Long time ago in one of the projects that I was working on we had to perform operations on stuff that were outside of single and double quotes. We used a regex similar to the one below to match them. If doing replace on the matched stuff is sufficient for solving this issue the solution is straightforward using the regex below. 

``` php
preg_split('/("[^"]*"|\'[^\']*\')/',$string,-1,PREG_SPLIT_DELIM_CAPTURE);
```

issue.title: Proposing sample code fix for issue #764
issue.body: The code attached can be used to solve the problem with the `negate()` method discussed in issue #764 . Tests covering the solution are available in AssertTest.php

issue.title: assertNotContains reports wrong message
issue.body: assertNotContains reports "[haystack] does not contain [needle]" as error message if haystack contains needle. It should report something like "[haystack] does contain [needle] and should not". It is a problem with wrong usage of the negation array. Its a negation of a negation.

issue.title: Assert-message manipulated?!
issue.body:
The assert-message seems to be manipulated by phpunit. I am searching in a string (html) and found the following: `Failed asserting that '
Product: ID is not invalid
' does not contain 'error'.` The correct error message is: `
Product: ID is invalid
`. Is it possible that _is_ is replaced by _is not_? I was very confused about this error message ;-)

body:
Dear contributor,

let me start by apologizing for not commenting and/or working on the issue you have reported or merging the pull request you have sent sooner.

PHPUnit 5.0 was released today. And today I am closing all open bug reports and pull requests for PHPUnit and its dependencies that I maintain. Please do not interpret the closing of this ticket as an insult or a lack of interest in your problem. I am sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

If the topic of this ticket is still relevant then please open a new ticket or send a new pull request. If your ticket or pull request is about a defect then please check whether the issue still exists in PHPUnit 4.8 (which will received bug fixes until August 2016). If your ticket or pull request is about a new feature then please port your patch PHPUnit 5.0 before sending a new pull request.

I hope that today's extreme backlog grooming will allow me to respond to bug reports and pull requests in a more timely manner in the future.

Thank you for your understanding,
Sebastian
